notesStmt.note: Losses to damp and mould in parchment and paper, infilled before rebinding. Tidemarks and mould spotting. Paling ink.

Folios 1-4 are parchment leaves of the 12th century, containing a portion of Homily IV of St. Chrysostom on Isaiah 6:1. Folio 5 is a paper flyleaf of the 17th to 18th century (partly folded), and contains a short piece in Hebrew dealing with the plague, followed by two pieces in Turkish (in Hebrew characters) on the same subject. Folios 6-8: notes and scribblings, partly illegible. Shelomoh Martin, perhaps a former owner, mentioned in two entries in connection with money transactions. Folios 1v-3v and 6r-8v, margins: a Hebrew-Turkish vocabulary, apparently of the 17th century.
Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

collation.p: 21 quires of originally 10, 8 and 12 leaves each, with parchment used for the two outer and the two inner leaves of a quire in the earlier part, and for the outer leaves only in the latter part.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Byzantine semi-cursive scripts of the 15th century.

binding.p: BM in-house. Spine: 'Shushan ha-Re'Phu'ah. Jekuthiel Ben Solomon's Versions of Lilium Medicinae. Hebrew. Brit. Mus. Additional 15,455.'

history.provenance: Acquisition: Purchased by the British Museum through Adolphus Asher(b. 1800, d. 1853), Berlin bookseller and dealer to the British Museum 1841-1853, on 08 March 1845: inscribed, folio 210v.
